I gain no pleasure writting this review, but as a disabled gamer on PC I expect certain challedge most do not...Yet some of the unforgiving crap this game gives is a reason for a negitive review. This is done by a disabled gamer who may have a difference critia from others but is a good propective on the game all the same

My base stats for this game:

Sound: 80% out of 100
Graphics: 85% out of 100
Controllers: 60% out of 100
Replay value: 50% out of 100 (will go into detail on this with controllers)
ADA (Americans with Disablities 508 complience) friendly: 60% out of 100%

Overwall Score is a 67%

Sound and Graphics: Going for a paraody on the megaman (x) series it wass done well. I can see a lot of Cuphead style boss design with borg implants. This game hits home with my love for 2d with a 3d rendering. The sound seems to get a lot of influence from 8-bit titles like Goonies and Capcom era games from the NES with a updated flow and modern remix. 


Controllers and ADA compilance: This is where the game has a lackluster tarish from having a higher overall. Where double forward gets you killed when you are use to Capcom's lovely interfere. The fact you have to smash the dash button mid-jump to use multi-dash jumps is a deal breaker for someone who has dextary or joint issuees. If you do not have these issues, count your self lucky but I do hold this against the title itself. Finding it is not ADA friendly is a huge issue in many games today. Some of the issues also stem from having less ground under you then Skiver's level in every single map or having more spikes then Alex the Red's level from MMX 5 where you need the ability to quickly pull out a series of dashes and jumps to have a chance....These controls should be refined with a beta tester who has experience with ADA or a disabled gamer to refine the layout. 

Replay value:....To add in"salt" to injury if you cannot finish the entire game on one life you lose everything. Not even Capcom at thier worst have they come close to making this mistake. This is "Angry Video Game Nerd rage worthy". It kills all fun of play in the fact that even in casual mode it is a kill joy. Mighty No 9 has better reseach and development in it practices. I would urge the developers to at least give a mode where one can keep the gear they collect and not punish those who have issues in mastering the game on thier insane diffculty curve. Besides that the levels are challedging and would feel like fun if the work was not so brutally punished for failure even to casual or disabled players. 

Overall: As with many indy developers I have reviewed over the years; it seems they have no clue as to what is good gameplay, too what is overly hard/easy, or even how to develop in a manner that supports good overall design for any player. This title is all too common to be riddled with flaws. The concept behind is niche, as it canters to a strived player community. That is acceptable but not giving a reasonable control system to allow for at least a par on the graceful controls of Capcom the IP owner of the original work this game is a paraody of shows the cheap feel that this game gives. That tarnishes all of the shinning achivement this game has for me and those like myself.

I will review if the developers of this game give these issues a deep overhual.

38638490.review:
[h1]Like rogue-lites? Enjoy platformers? Miss the good ol' Megaman X games? Then this is a MUST buy.[/h1]

[b]++The Positive++[/b]
+Tight and responsive controls, and they're both intuitive for veterans, as well as easy to learn for beginners.
+CO-OP in a good MM-esque game!! This is enough to warrant the already reasonable price of the game. 
+Varied and enjoyable level design, which not only pays homage to X's design but also introduces new and fun challenges, kept ever varied thanks to the solid level randomization.
+Solid progression, with a decent number of upgrades both permanent and temporal for each run.
+The difficulty, which feels just right for this kind of games and motivates you to learn enemy and obstacle patterns, successfully balancing fun and rewarding experiences, making it just hard enough that when you lose a run you will immediately start a new one. Sincerely I've felt none of the frustration that other rogue-likes have given me before. Finally, the option to disable upgrades for runs, as well as daily challenges and keeps it interesting.
+Pretty good sound design, with the music and SFX complementing the game well enough.


[b]<<The Neutral>>[/b]
>I've read comments about the graphics which, yes, could be called simplistic, even flash-esque, but really, they're serviceable, and merely a matter of taste. In my opinion, they're good enough and mostly enjoyable pieces of bit art except perhaps for some of the bosses.
>The Bosses themselves could use some variety, but nothing too noticeable to detract from the experience.

[b]--The Negative--[/b]
-Nothing really in my opinion, I love this game and I believe most MM fans will as well.

[h1]The Final Verdict[/h1]
20XX is a real throwback to Megaman X's games that will scratch that decades long itch of its fans, but can also stand on it's own without depending on nostalgia to deliver a solid gameplay experience.
In short, I've had the most fun playing this game than any other in months, and I recommend it to anyone who loves the Megaman series, platformers, or rogue-lites in general.

Batterystaple Games and Fire Hose Games, thank you for making this, you're awesome!

38588980.review:
Yeah, yeah, yeah. Mega Man it is not. It is an excellent attempt at putting a twist on a genre which has done a ton, thus far. I dare say that this game does deserve the accolades that it gets, though. Here's the thing, intellectual properties are like Rubiks cubes, put a couple of twists on them and you have something new. The question is, does that new combination work. Since 20XX left early access and fully released, I would say yes! The controls are tight, the homage to MM and MMX in term of level design, music, and bosses, are there without being a blatant rip off of the very idea it so clearly idolizes. In essence, there is a ton to do, and much more than what can be covered with a simple 2 hour playthrough.

Give it some time, patience, and understanding, much like any other game. You'll be rewarded with an entertaining, frustrating, challenging, and delightful experience.

Good job, devs!!

Vous voulez faire pleurer un trentenaire, fan de jeu vidéo? Dites leur megaman et il pleurera, jeu adulé qui a été complètement abandonné par Capcom.

La relève semblait  venir de Mighty N°9, un projet du "papa de Megaman" (qui n'en est même pas le père). 
LA foule s'est excitée, les fond ont plu sur le studio, c'était la fête.  jusqu’à la débacle
Pendant ce temps, un petit outsider a pris le parti de reprendre cette inspiration, en y ajoutant des éléments de Roguelike (run procéduraux, déblocables qui aident à rendre les prochains runs moins abruptes,...)

20XX propose donc de suivre un petit robot bleu aussi charismatique que ma cafetière (coucou josianne, je t'aime)  dans une série de niveau qui mélange habilement plateforme et les combats. La génération procédurale est plutot correcte, même si j'ai eu rapidement l'impression de refaire les mêmes séquences, particulièrement dans les premiers niveaux. En fait le jeu fonctionne comme ceci: dans les premiers niveaux, le jeu pioche des éléments dans un sac et le sac propose de plus en plus d'éléments au fur et à mesure que vous progressez dans les niveaux.

Tout comme les boss: les premières versions des boss sont faciles mais si vous les croisez plus tard, il sera plus complexe à battre.

Ajoutez à cela des unlockables qui sont suffisamment sympa que pour varier les manières de jouer même si on est trèèèèèèès loin de la variété gargantuesque que peut proposer un BoI.

On regrettera un emballage terne qui n'aiderait pas un dépressif à revoir la beauté du monde. C'est moche et la bande sonore, même si elles s'inspire de Megaman m'a fait saigner des oreilles.

Les aficionados de roguelite plateformer y trouveront un bon compagnon, malgré quelques flottement dans les contrôles, le dash reste compliqué à utiliser je trouve, il faut sauter et puis appuyer sur la touche dash, le saut obligatoire est superflu, tout comme le fait de rester coller au mur demande de garder la touche de direction vers le mur mais quand tu dois sauter dans le sens opposé, t'as interet à être rapide, sinon, le robot se "décroche" du mur et tombe.

 Je rale un peu là sur les derniers paragraphes mais sincèrement, si vous aimez les roguelite avec des passages plateformers, je vous le conseille, faites vous plaisir les masochistes.

38465361.review:
Excellent game!! Definitely my favorite side-scroller on Steam. This game combines Megaman X with the mechanics of "rogue-likes" to make a excellent experience with plenty of replay value. As someone who plays through Megaman X about once a year, this game is a godsend.

While it is clearly influenced by the Megaman X series, in differs for all the right reasons. Since it is a roguelike you do not keep boss weapons between playthroughs, you get cool stuff much quicker than MMX, it gets much harder than MMX as it progresses, etc. These are all good in my opinion since it adds a lot of challenge and replay value to the game. Unlike MMX, there is a lot of balance to weapons, and like MMX, every weapon has some use outside of dealing damage.

20XX really is well designed game, and a great title for people who enjoy anything Megaman.

38386587.review:
Großartiger Plattformer im Stile von Megaman X. In 20XX müsst ihr euch wie in den Klassikern von Capcom durch 8 Level mit ihrem jeweiligen Boss durchkämpfen, bevor ihr euch aufmachen könnt, in den finalen Leveln den Endgegner zu bezwingen. Es gibt auch in 20XX (bisher) zwei Charaktere: Nina, die wie Megaman X verschiedene Projektile aus ihrer Armkanone schießen kann, und Ace, der seinem Schwertkämpferkollegen Zero entspricht. Beide Charaktere können die Fähigkeiten besiegter Bosse übernehmen und in den darauffolgenden Leveln verwenden.

Der große Unterschied zu den Megaman-X-Spielen sind die Roguelike-Elemente. Genauer gesagt handelt es sich hierbei um [b]Permadeath[/b] und [b]prozedural generierte Level[/b]. Permadeath bedeutet lediglich, dass ihr nur ein Leben habt (es gibt zwar einen leichten Modus mit zwei Extraleben, der ist aber mehr für absolute Anfänger gedacht und lässt einen auch keine Errungenschaften/Achievements freischalten) und am Ende jedes Spiels all eure Ausrüstung und Upgrades verliert (egal, ob ihr verliert oder gewinnt). Ihr könnt jedoch während des Spiels sogenannte Soulchips einsammeln, mit denen ihr anschließend in eurem Hauptquartier stärkere Upgrades freischalten könnt, die dann in zukünftigen Game-Sessions auftauchen können. (Es sei jedoch betont, dass ihr das komplette Spiel auch völlig ohne jegliche Upgrades durchspielen könnt, wenn ihr gut genug seid.)

Prozedural generierte Level bedeutet, dass jede Runde anders ist, da sich alle Level jedes Mal, wenn ihr spielt, verändern, was den Wiederspielwert von 20XX immens erhöht. Level werden quasi auf zufällige Weise aus handgefertigten Levelstücken zusammengesetzt und Upgrades und Gegner werden nach einem bestimmten Schwierigkeitsschema (also je weiter ihr gekommen seid, desto schwieriger werden die Gegner) zufällig platziert.

Wer sich an diesen beiden Merkmalen nicht stört, den wird 20XX garantiert nicht enttäuschen. Die Steuerung des Spiels ist einsame Spitze (Tipp: Vsync im Spielemenü ausschalten) und der Wiederspielwert ist, wie bereits erwähnt, extrem hoch (man siehe meine Spielzeit). Es gibt übrigens auch eine deutsche Übersetzung, die zumindest das Gütesiegel „ausreichend“ verdient, jedoch ist das Spiel, denke ich, selbst mit rudimentären Englischkenntnissen nicht allzu schwer zu verstehen.

38382571.review:
Having played this game from the Alpha release, I can personally say that this is one of the best indie games I have ever played. The game scratches the itch left by the absence of megaman games in the last 7 years, with the last (actual) megaman game coming out on May the 1st 2010. It feels just like a megaman game should be, having smooth controls (which can be changed depending on your preference), an incredible soundtrack, and great character designs.

[u] 20xx is a rogue like [/u]. If you have played rogue likes before, you of course know how things are with the genre. But for those who do not know, a rogue like is a genre of game where the player character is sent into a procedurely generated level and have to reach it to the end of said level, completing whatever challenge the game presents you with. You also will in fact lose whatever items you recieved during your run when you die (aside from certain acceptions). Throughout the game you will slowly unlock new items to encounter and obtain throughout your runs,  this encourages the player to keep playing and unlock all there is to obtain. Also as a final note on rogue likes, they tend to be quite difficult so you will hopefully get better as a gamer in general thanks to the challenge presented (that, or you will stop playing the game for whatever reason you might have, which is of course fine).

[u] On to the design aspect of the game [/u]. 20xx has a 32-bit feel to it and it personally makes me feel nostalgic, having really gotten into platforming games because of Megaman X4. The sprites also of course have the said 32-bit feel to them, and have gone through alot of changes throughout the different patches for the game. The Bosses all have unique designs (some very reminiscent of early Megaman X bosses) that all have a borderlands style intro slide. 

But that is all I will say so as to not cheapen the experience of the game for those who don't really want any kind of spoiler whatsoever, so here are my ending thoughts. 20xx is a great game to hold over megaman fans until the recently announced [u] Megaman 11 [/u] is released. The game is very unique and has a ton of personality. And while the game does have it's flaws, the overall experience you get from this game is great and will surely keep you coming back if you like platformers. 
So take it from a long time platforming veteran, if you like platforming games, you will like this game. So please give it a shot, and if you don't like it go ahead and refund it. It's ultimately your choice on what you want to try, buy, or whatever. But if you have the time I highly suggest that you try playing this game.
Have a good day.

38293994.review:
This is the first review I've written on steam in 7 years. I have 120 hours in this game. Let me tell you how much of a gem this game is.

It has the control tightness of Super Meat Boy with the insane power-ups of a game like Prototype, couched in Megaman-style game mechanics and aesthetics. In a word, it's addicting.

Prior to it's 1.0 release, the game had *weekly* updates. To me, that tells me the devs 1) care about the game 2) care about the player base 3) rock and deserve free beer. When you launched the game, the game literally had a countdown indicating how long until the next update. No one playing post-1.0 will know that, no one who wasn't a beta player will know that, but it should be underscored and remembered. Every week, when my 20XX update started auto-downloading, I would always play because I would wonder what new powers they put into the game this week.

If you're reading this you probably already have a sense of what the gameplay is like, so instead of telling you about the gameplay let me tell you about the game design. The devs included Halo-style "skulls" which modify some aspect of the game. These skulls can be turned on/off, in any combination. 

In the beta, dying meant losing all of the upgrades you've picked up on your current run. This is still true, but now you get the chance to re-buy some of the upgrades before starting your run. If you don't want to, you don't have to, but this gives players who don't want to start from zero the option to start their next run with a bit of a buff.

Another optional tweak the devs give you: the power-up drops in this game are random, but suppose you really hate some particular power-up. The devs added a neat "de-program" mechanic, which lets you eliminate some power-ups from randomly dropping in your upcoming run. This, like the "re-buy" mechanic feature I discussed above, costs "soul chips", which you pick up during a run. So these features are balanced in the sense that you can only re-buy and de-program according to how well you did on a previous run. 

The key with both of these features is they are optional. The devs give you so many options it's mind-boggling to me how big name game companies don't invite these devs as consultants for their projects. You have the option to use skulls, the option to start runs with upgrades, or to start with just your normal weapon, and you have the option de-program power-ups. 

TLDR: buy this game. It's easily worth 29.99CAD, but it's 16.99CAD regular price. If it's on sale, buy it for yourself and send the devs some love by buying it for a friend.

38246116.review:
I bought 20XX while searching for a game similar to Mega Man X. What a great surprise! I'm really amazed with this game. I've got much more than I was looking for.

Here is a "short" description of the features of the game:

Characters:
Nina and Ace. Both are similar to Mega Man X and Zero. Nina has a buser, that shots forward, and Ace has a Saber that slashes enemies close to him. Both can charge their attacks, doubling the damage output.

Weapons:
You can find other weapons while progressing the game to replace the default one. For example, Nina has a weapon that can fire four shots in the cardinal directions, and Ace has a Spear that can extend the range of his attacks.

Special Powers:
When you defeat a boss you have a choice to get his power, or another items. Each poer is unique and you can equip three special powers at a time, on different buttons. You can manage your active special powes on the pause menu.

Bosses:
There are 8 bosses (excluding the final ones). Each boss has a unique power, and is weak to another boss power. Much like Mega Man series. The difficulty of each boss increase as you progress through the stages.

Armors:
There are 4 sets of armor, each one has 4 pieces: chest, foot, arms and helmet. Each piece for each set has an specific effect. For example, you can dash in the air, or double jump, get an extra charge for your weapon, use less energy for you special attacks, etc. You can use different pieces from different sets, or try to collect an entire set to get an extra bonus effect. 

Items:
On the Mega Man X Series, we had a few items, that could replenish or raise your health/energy. On 20XX we have many stats (movement speed, height of jump, attack power, and so on) that can be modified with items and power ups. Some items will give a minor increments, while others can give a huge boost in one stat, while decreasing other. Items can be found in shops on the stages, on special chests, or after defeating a boss.

Currency:
There are three currecies in this game:
Nuts: You receive those from chests or eneies. You can use them to buy items on shops, or exchange to HP and Energy on some machines.
Tokens: In some stages, before the boss room, you may find a slot machine, where you can use those items. You may receive a power up item, some pick-ups or, if you are unlucky, nothing.
Soul Chips: Some special enemies drops those chips, that can be used to unlock new items, to be used on future runs.

Stages:
In 20XX the stages are randomly generated, so each run is unique. There is no fixed place for power ups, armor pieces and other items. There is no guarantee you will find an specific item in you run. 
You cannot choose the first boss you will fight, and after beating the first stage, you have can choose between three bosses to proceed. They are not in a specific order, and you may not find the weapon of the previous boss useful against the next.
There is usually one shop (sometimes two, one of them right before the boss). Also, you may find a Glory ZOne in the middle of the stage. When entering on this room, you have a task to perform. If you are successful, you will get a piece of armor. Those tasks involve destroying enemies, reach the end of the room without damage, disabling traps, etc.
Due to this random feature, the replayability of the game is enormous. You may have a very hard run, or you may become so powerful that you can destroy the bosses in a blink of an eye.
On normal mode, you have only one life, but there is no instant kill traps. Pits and spikes cause only damage. You can always adjust this selecting another difficulty setting.

The Ark:
This is the place where you start, and where you come back after a run. From here you can choose to play a game, select another mode (daily challenges, special runs, etc), switch characters, and unlock items or buy them to use on the next runs, with Soul Chips.

Multiplayer:
You can play with a friend! The game will zoom in and out depending on the proximity of the players. The boss door will only open when both player reach it. If a player die, the other will continue alone until he can find a capsule to ressurrect the first. Power Ups picked by one player will affect the other. Armor pieces will appear in pairs, one for each player. It is possible to use two Ninas or two Aces. Tottally fun. I just wished there was a fight mode between players :)


I already said too much and there is still a lot of good things I could mention about this game. The graphics are great, the animation of the characters is awesome, the response of the controls is perfet!

I highly reccommend the game. The price is very fair, and you will have lots of fun.

38240958.review:
I've played 20xx since it was in early access and I've always considered it one of the best roguelike/lite games. 
However when the game was released with the option of having permanent upgrades I have to admit that my heart sank. 

In the early days there were no permanent upgrades and when you died, you lost everything and had to start again. This in my opinion is how the game should have stayed. 
This was a game that I always went back to again and again to try to complete it and I had a lot of fun doing it. 

You went through the game hoping for that perfect run and upgrading yourself along the way. If you died, you lost it all and had to try again. 

Adding permanent upgrades means that you can basically start the game with an op weapon and a massive health bar and get to the end of the game really quickly which wasn't what the game was about when I played it. 

Don't get me wrong the permanent upgrades are optional and you can leave them off if you want to but anyone new to the game isn't going to have the same experience of 20xx that I had and I feel that's a great shame. 
I do highly recommend the game. It's an excellent challenging platformer with great graphics and controls. I just wish it was released without the permanent upgrade option. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9WXDoQIE_I

38213561.review:
Claro derivado de Megaman que coge todo lo bueno de la saga y lo rehace a su manera. Divide el juego en dos personajes: uno que lucha a melee y otro completamente basado en Rockman y convierte el mapa en secciones/zonas creados de forma "aleatoria" para no aburrir al jugador a cada nuevo intento. La única y principal función del juego es entretener y este entretenimiento se basa en la jugabilidad, no esperéis una historia ni nada mínimamente serio.

Pros:
- Precio.
- Música.
- Multijugador.
- Gran variedad de enemigos, jefes finales, items, etc.
- Suficientemente aleatorio como para que cada experiencia sea diferente pero sin dejar de ser skill based.

Conts:
- No tiene personalidad ni expone nada nuevo o diferente al género.
- Al no recibir una verdadera recompensa o avance en una trama, el "final" puede llegar a resultar lejano y el juego monótono.

Dedicado a gente que no tenga mucho tiempo para jugar, que solo busquen una experiencia rápida y casual o que sean seguidores de la entrega de Capcom. Es un videojuego que ofrece lo que promete: diversión.

38088903.review:
'록맨' 당하지 않은, 진정한 록맨 게임. 정확히는 록맨X 시리즈의 그것들을 많이 가져왔다고 보면 된다.
필자는 클래식 록맨보다는 록맨X4이후 록맨시리즈(에그제, 제로, 젝스 등)를 접한 사람이기에 클래식 록맨을 좋아하는 사람과는 조금 시각이 다를 수도 있을 수도 있다.

장점은
록맨X시리즈의 향수와 재미를 느낄 수 있다는 점, 록맨X가 8이후로 소식이 없어 암이 걸렸는데 이 게임을 하고 나았다.
그리고 여타 록맨의 정신적 후속작이나 영감을 받았다는 게임들 그리고 '그 게임마저' 대부분이 록버스터만을 생각할 때, 이 게임은 제로의 써는 맛을 살렸다.
특수무기 죄다 무시하고 기본공격 올인하고 근접에서 보스를 썰어버리는 맛이 제대로다.

단점은
로크라이크 방식이라서 록맨X 특유의 무기모아서 약점공격으로 잡기 및 보스 선택을 통한 공략루트 개척 등이 없어진 게 조오금 아쉽다.
물론 로그라이크가 안 익숙한 필자의 취향이지만 록맨시리즈인데 콜렉팅이 안된다는 건 역시 아쉽다.
특수무기가 죄다 니나나 에이스가 동일하다는 점도 안타깝다. 에이스만의 공격형태를 만들어주는 것도 좋을텐데...물론 이것도 필자의 취향이다.
마지막으로 게임이 좀 불친절하다. 약점상성관계 및 아이템의 세부적 스테이터스를 설명해줘야하는데, 그런게 없다. 특히 초안전연구소 물건들. 구글링해보니 영어로 정리되있는게 있긴하던데,
인게임에서 설명해주면 더 좋지않을까...한다. 솔직히 즐거운시간이라는 아이템은 다음 두레벨의 수치를 랜덤설정한다는데, 그런걸 어떻게 게임내에서 알아내라는건지 원....

사실 단점이라고 나열한 것의 대부분이 기존의 록맨에서 보여주던 틀과 다르기 때문에 나온 것들인데(아이템설명이나 상성은 좀 확실히 명시되었으면...아님 암시라던가),그것만 아니면 이 게임은 확실히 록맨X의 정신적 후속작이라고 칭할만 하다.
록맨X팬이라면 정가 주고 사도 좋다.
게다가 이 게임은 지금 작성하고있는 2017년 말에도 사후 업데이트를 계속해준다. 이게 진짜 갓겜아니냐?

38005927.review:
While it is a fun time and somewhat nostalgic, it has an over-reliance on timed moving platforms, lasers, and stationary fireball shooters.  The powers are not quite as fun to use as they are in the MM/MMX series and have little purpose outside of boss fights, aside from the occasional tricky to hit enemy.  Health and power restorative items are few and far between, though these is common in rogue-likes.

All in all it is fun to play right up until the areas that require precision timing, then it drifts into the realm of only playable by 'elitists' who enjoy that sort of thing.

38000263.review:
A great game for Megaman X styled platformers. While I don't have any experience with the other game that inspired 20XX, the aspects that weren't Megaman I did enjoy. It is quite challenging, but only rarely did I feel that the game wasn't working properly which may have been a result of some salt on my end. Playing it patiently and taking your time platforming is key to get through some levels, especially the Sky Temple area. 

The Bosses aren't too difficult to deal with, but some are more difficult than others. Though I haven't tried any difficult modes yet so take this with a grain of salt.

The art I enjoyed, as it was colorful and unique while also paying homage to the games that inspired it. The soundtrack I did enjoy, but not something I'd play in my car. 

I'd recommend this to those who liked the Megaman X series or platformers in general. It's a fun time but expect to have some challenges in the road ahead.

37990608.review:
很久才等来一次打折，之前一直在玩盗版，实际游戏时间大概十小时左右。
有人把20xx里的战士和洛克人zero系列比较，其实这两者差异极大，20xx的难度相比zero系列低了不止一个等级。

最明显的一点就是视野，zero系列的视野很狭窄，经常会出现跑着跑着撞到前面冲过来的轮胎或者别的什么敌人而损血的情况。20xx的镜头拉得非常远，敌人出现后玩家有足够的时间来作出反应。

武器方面，20xx的a-saber简直就是40米长刀。。。。而zero系列中的z-saber长度很微妙，要把控好自己与敌人的距离不太容易。20xx里主角的机动性完全由捡到的装备来提升，如二段跳和空中飞行，而zero系列需要用各种武器比如链子和拐来达成各种骚操作。

战斗方面，20xx的怪物数量要比zero系列多得多，且生命值要高。初始的asaber和绞肉机应该是20xx里最实用的两把武器，asaber距离远伤害低，绞肉机范围小伤害高。攻击方式只有民工三连，没有跳劈冲砍升龙等技能，帅气度大打折扣。打死boss给的技能除了护盾类几乎没有丝毫卵用。。。。
zero系列砍死一只怪不是一刀就是两刀，不行就再来一刀，一般情况下民工三连都能解决问题。而实际上zero系列中民工三连并不常用，需要一定技巧的跳劈和冲砍才是最保险最方便的攻击方式。

20xx的boss本来应当不见得会比zero系列的更简单的，zero系列boss房一般是空荡荡的一片，只需要躲避boss技能，而20xx的boss关需要跳平台，增加了闪避难度。但是20xx被攻击一次只损一格血，还能增加生命值上限，甚至能在打boss前回血？！可怜我zero顶多被摸个五次就炸了，就算能穿过小兵撑到boss房也不可能是满状态。。。。

地形方面，20xx里移动平台极多，然而并不难跳，很多地方可以蹭无敌跑过去。实际体验后还是zero系列难些。

总体说来，如果你一定要把20xx和洛克人系列混为一谈的话，难度已经极度亲民了（就算是和x系列相比）
其实这个游戏最大的问题是关卡重复度太高，我十个小时就已经腻了，希望以后能增加些新的模式

ローグライクロックマンX。

ライフがなくなるまで自動生成されるステージを突破し８体のボス＋αを倒すことが目的。
しかしこのゲームの敵とはそれらのボスではなく、ステージギミックである。
消える足場、動く足場、跳ねる足場。これらをいかに落ちずに渡っていくかというのがゲームの肝となっている。
そしてボスを倒していくに従いステージの難易度が上がっていき、
足場に加えて横に撃つ砲台、上から落ちる氷柱、点滅するビームが行く手を阻む。
それが最終ステージ、最終ボスまで続いていく。
繰り返しプレイをすることにより難易度を下げることは可能だが、
１回のプレイにおけるパターンがあまりに少なすぎる。
単なるアクションが好きならば問題なく楽しめるのかもしれないが、
ローグライクという言葉にランダム性を重視するのであればオススメはできない。

37868591.review: I returned this game but I would still recommend it to somebody if they are aren't looking for a polished platformer like Mega Man. If you're more interested in the roguelike gameplay then get it on sale and have a great time but Mega Man it is not.  Randomly generated levels will never provide the same challenge or feel as your basic platformer with fixed levels, it's just not possible. The enemies became very repetitive within my 2 hour playtime and the levels shared the same problem. This game isn't bad but it's really not what I was expecting and I wouldn't pay more than $3 for it.

37859193.review:
20XX is the most Mega Man-like game to ever Mega as any Man could. And that man is Chris King. This guy and his team spent years bringing to life something thousands of people had no idea they wanted: A Mega Man X-styled rogue-like. ure, the levels and upgrades are different every run, but it's the amount of options, playstyles and presentation here that really shines through an art style that not a lot of people are into. 

However, once you get into it, and feel how smoothly it controls and how fun it is to play, you'll realize that THIS is what people have been wanting from Capcom's old flagship franchise that hasn't seen a new entry in years.

And it's fun!

Major props to the dev, one of my favorite people to ever had the pleasure of interacting with, and one who still supports the game and takes all feedback into consideration no matter what. Applaud this man, and buy this game!

37854334.review: Un maravilloso viaje al pasado. Un juego lleno de magia, pasión por los detalles y un gran homenaje a uno de los grandes clásicos de los videojuegos. Sin dudas, es el verdadero sucesor de Rockman (Megaman). Gráficos soberbios, control perfecto y la posibilidad de jugar cooperativo (online y offline), hacen de este juego una de esas pequeñas grandes joyas no tan conocidas. Si sos de los que te gustan los juegos difíciles o te gusta hacer Speedrun, es un juego que no podes dejar pasar. Recomendadísimo a full, no decepciona en lo absoluto.

20XX is my favorite rogue-lite platformer which also happens to be my favorite genre of game. 

The art is fantastic and the controls are very tight. The randomness of the levels/upgrades keeps you coming back for more and more runs. It's friendly to beginners and with difficulty skulls enabled can present a great challenge. 

It's like playing Megaman but with the edges polished making it easy to pick up, yet still nostalgia inducing without all the little frustrations of revisiting old games. I've already bought three copies for friends and it will be my go to gift in the future. Would recommend.

ゲームの内容を簡単に上げるとすれば
[list]
 [*]オンライン、ローカルでの2人プレイが可能。
 [*]キャラはバスターの[b]Nina[/b]、セイバーの[b]Ace[/b]の2人
 [*]毎回マップは自動生成でプレイする度に違います。
 [*]オーグメントというプレイヤーを強化するアイテムが有り
 [*]またコアオーグメント（〇ックマンで言う所のパワーアップパーツ）が頭、胴、腕、脚の4部位×4種
 [*]武器はバスター側、セイバー側で5種類ずつ。
 [*]8種類のパワー（特殊武器）装備があります。
 [*]ボスは全部で[spoiler]10[/spoiler]体。
 [*]死んでしまうとオーグメントやパワーは無くなり、また1からというローグライク
 [*]エンドレスモード在り
 [*]もう堂々とストアに〇ックマンと書いてます。
[/list]
っとこんな感じの〇ックマンです。

Don't let the flash-esque animation turn you off, it's a great "roguelite" action platformer.
Gameplay is straight from Megaman X so expect dash jumping all day, it's fun and controls are very responsive.
There are a lot of items to unlock and with the daily challenges, it leaves the game open to be played a lot.
Overall the difficulty is fine, it relies more on your knowledge and capacity to deal with foes/traps than items rng and if you want something more challenging, you can use modifiers to customize it.
Last, but not least, there is online co-op which is really fun with a friend.
I had a blast with 20XX, I didn't expect it to be so good.	
However, I wish each boss had their own stage and some cut-scenes/art could use a rework.

37458533.review: Imperfect, but a real blast. I admit, the random-generation aspects probably don't do the level design a lot of favors - they lose that lovingly handcrafted feel you see in the game's not-at-all-concealed source material. But the randomized powerups and enhancements do lend some fun and give each run its own distinct character. My chief complaint overall would be the kinda inorganic, "paper doll"-esque animations, where characters' limbs are mostly animated by just pivoting them on their joints rather than actually hand-drawing unique animations. But the immensely replayable reasonable challenge these games pose, and the fun of two player mode, thoroughly eclipses nitpicks like that. On top of all that, the devs have done a great job with continuing to hone and tweak the game post-release, including new content!

37252143.review:
Honestly, this is what a Megaman successor should've been, not THAT other mess, but I'm here to talk about this great game.

Controlwise, this game feel solid in it's movements and move speed, the only issue I had was not being used to the button for dashing being one of the bumpers, but easily solved via keymapping it on options menu.

Gameplay wise, Levels being procedurally generated makes it quite interesting to play it, for once you die you can throw out your old level strategy to the garbage, it's time to plan on the move.
The bosses were fun, my only gripe there being how you're limited to 3 powers at any time, so in addition you have to strategize your best course possible if you wanna make it through it.
Multiplayer is just one of the many things I've been waiting for these types of game, it's hillariously good.

Soundtrack wise, its a blast to the past, taking you back to your old SNES and PS1 era, just great to go along with this game.

Overall, I loved this game, it's rather challenging, and the added difficulty badges make it a real challenge if you wish it to be, though I'd avoid putting all the Speed Augment modifiers to the game, it becomes HELL.

36637004.review:
А вы помните Мегамена (или Рокмена, как в японском оригинале... впрочем, это не столь важно, ибо я сейчас не буду распинаться о том, как же загадили переводы игр серии своими адаптациями при официальных переводах на английский)? Если да, то вы также наверняка помните не только о серии игр на NES... Наверное... Может быть вы ещё помните о серии X и хотя бы слышали о шикарной (по крайней мере для меня) серии Zero? Это я сейчас о хороших частях франшизы, а не тех, что были испорчены какими-то деталями от кривого управления до диалогов там, где они не нужны и откровенно мешают...

Я так понимаю, что все кто ещё это читает слышали о Mighty No. 9 и то каким провалом почти во всём она оказалась. Можете радоваться, можете нет, но я также и не о ней сейчас расскажу. Ибо её я упомянул лишь для того, чтобы ещё раз напомнить, что создатель оригинальной франшизы может быть кардинально слеп по поводу того, чем же людям полюбилась игра, к созданию которой он был причастен.

Итак, инди проект 20XX от фанатов серии игр про Мегамена. И геймплейно это именно то, ради чего я играл в те игры. Но всё же надо рассказать немного подробней и по критериям...

Сюжет:
Ну... он есть, правда скорее для галочки... Да, это скорее минус, ибо в том же Зеро, к примеру, захватывал и сюжет, и геймплей... и собственно всё остальное. Здесь же сюжет есть, но он для галочки, из-за чего не захватывает, а просто вводит в курс дела. 

Геймплей/Механики: 
Они почти полностью повторяют хорошие части серии X и сольные игры Zero: прыжки от стен, способности боссов, разные виды оружия, рывки, прыжок с рывком и прочее... Способности также влияют на некоторые элементы уровней, например, можно заморозить огненные турели.

Музыка: 
Достаточно подходящая по атмосфере к данному геймплею и графике, о которой я, пока что не сказал... Мне сложно описывать музыку, так что скажу лишь это.

Графика: 
Пытается быть в стиле вышеупомянутых серий, но всё-равно более мультяшная, что, впрочем, всё-равно выглядит не плохо.

Так, это было только общее, теперь то, что осталось...

Игру надо проходить за один заход, ну или сохраняться и выходить, а потом продолжать этот же заход... Сохранение возможно только со специальной станции после босса, да и вернуться на станцию после этого без потери забега не получится... То есть надо пройти за забег или умереть. 

Есть станция, она как меню, в котором надо управляя персонажем выбрать за кого вы хотите играть, выбрать апгрейды (которые также можно просто вырубить), перепройти обучение, зайти в испытания (ежедневные, еженедельные и т.д.).

Есть два играбельных персонажа один из которых стреляет из пушки как Мегамен, а другой дерётся мечом как Зеро.

Апгрейды, которые можно покупать за валюту, которая выпадает из особых более сильных светящихся врагов во время забега.

Три уровня сложности:
1. Простой с тремя жизнями, с апгрейдами, без засчитывания ачивок.
2. Средний, одна жизнь, с апгрейдами.
3. Сложный, без апгрейдов, с усложняющими игру модификаторами

Итак, почему же я говорю о забегах? Кроме того, что игру надо пройти с одной попытки, то есть убить всех боссов за один заход, там также есть генерация уровней постепенно повышающаяся общая сложность (виды генерации, уровни врагов и прочее) этих самых уровней, то есть один и тот же уровень будет кардинально разный по сложности при прохождении его первым и условно последним (условно, ибо последним, какой можно выбрать самому). А также есть предметы и броня, которые выпадают с сундуков, которые надо добывать с мини испытаний на самих уровнях... Или покупать в магазине на собранные со врагов болты. Из-за этого повышается реиграбельность и вариативность игры. Также нельзя будет пройти игру просто заучив локации. Здесь поможет только скилл.

В общем, я считаю, что фанаты постарались и сделали достойного преемника своей любимой франшизы... в отличии от Mighty No. 9...

36634827.review:
I don't normally write reviews but I have to on this game. 

I've been playing this game for two years and I have seen it improve a lot. Yes, the basics were all there and you knew what the devs were trying to do, and it worked, it was fun. But now that the game is a few months released, the game is so polished. I look back on the old videos of people playing and it has come a long way. Granted, I'm not too terribly concerned with graphics, gameplay is what matters and boy does this deliver.

I really have nothing bad to say about it besides it has quite a skill curve and it's tough to get far at the beginning while you are unlocking items for future runs. But that is all a part of the challenge and you feel a sense of progression. Also, it's hard to get my RL friends into it because you need a few hours to figure out the intricacies of the controls. 

I grew up playing mega man X. Probably the first game I ever rented at blockbuster. I rented it probably 3 more times after that. I've played them all. This game truly does scratch that itch for me. When I found out there were different upgrades for your character, that sealed the deal. I love it so much. 

The controls are tight and if I mess up, it's my fault.

This review is kind of all over the place, but get the game if you love platformers of any kind. It is a great game!

36601495.review:
록맨 인디 게임 명작


록맨 본가가 망한 이후, 그리고 이나후네 케이지의 Mighty No.9의 자멸 이후. 내가 본 록맨 인디 게임 중에선 가장 잘 만들었다고 생각 한다. (푸른 뇌정 건볼트도 있지만, 그것은 인디게임이 아니므로 패스.)

Mighty No. 9 보다는 스토리 부분이나 그래픽 적인 부분에선 (크게 차이는 없지만) 조금 부족하지만,  게임플레이가 모든 것을 보충 하고도 남는다. 클래식 시리즈의 특징과 X 시리즈의 특징을 잘 섞은 플레이가 인상적이며, 레벨업 요소, 무기 탈취 시스템도 가지고 있어서 지루하지 않다.

다만, 스테이지가 랜덤으로 생성이 되다 보니 스타트가 안좋으면 오래 가지 못한다는 점이 단점이며, 이지를 제외하면 목숨이 1개 뿐인것도 상당히 어렵게 작용한다. 가시 같은 즉사 함정이 없다는게 그나마 위안.

그리고... 번역 상태가 좋지 않다. 오히려 약간 병맛 스러운 번역이 게임의 분위기와 박사의 성격을 잘 표현하는것 같기도 하지만, 확실히 부자연 스러운건 맞다.


록맨을 좋아하는 사람이라면, 정가를 주고 사도 전혀 후회없이 즐길 수 있을 것이다.

The variability and customization of challenges, the random-generation, the huge variety of upgrades; everything comes together to give this game some serious replay value. The ONLY criticism I have is that they skimped on maps by having 8 bosses utilize 4 map-types (and therefore 4 level soundtracks). 36575743.review:
I enjoyed this game various times, but I don't think I'll be playing it again.
I clocked in a couple of hours alone, and about 2 hours with my brother (we both played the original Megaman series on the nes & snes).

It was really fun, even dieing was fun and funny.

My/our issues: (1) no real sense of progression and (2) there are only 4 tilemaps for levels so even though its "procedurally generated" you always end up with more or less the 4 same stages themes, who cares if the bosses are different they are only at the end anyways, it just gets repetitive pretty fast...

The bosses were also pretty easy, their patterns where very easily identified and so playing the "procedural levels" and getting to the same bosses everytime gets very repetitive very fast.

For 15$ I think this game is expensive but I enjoyed it. Im an aspiring Indie dev as well so I'm not getting a refund in order to support Chris, even though my 15$ isn't going to make or break him. I just feel like there is a general lack of content in this product and hopefully the Developer is willing to add in some more tilemaps just to change the feel of the levels which would do a great deal of difference.

36560441.review:
This game does what it set out to do (Megaman X gameplay in a roguelite format) pretty well, the movement and combat and whatnot is all solid and fun. I like the leg/body/hand/head powerups in particular, though offering a nice extra bonus for collecting a full set is kind of cruel since that'll only happen when the stars align (once for me in 10 hours of gameplay).

The surprising thing was how relatively easy it was, not that it's a cakewalk but once I had a decent understanding of the game bosses went down pretty quickly and most of my failed runs came from it generating ridiculously difficult platforming segments (the second to last stage is guaranteed to have some), especially if I had the poor luck to not get a movement upgrade. 

I wouldn't mind a bit more stage/boss variety, you'll always encounter the same stages and bosses on any given run, but it does look like the game is still getting updates even though it's out of Early Access (including hints of a 3rd playable character), I could see myself coming back to it later.

36527557.review:
Quite enjoy this game. Its strongest point, to me, is its pinpoint controls; no wasted motion, no sliding, no committed-length jumps. Controller support is on point, too. This is a standard-bearer for platformer controls. 

The aesthetic is fun and colorful, attacks are flashy and the destruction animations/sfx are crunchy and satisfying in a way that even Megaman X wasn't. 

There are two comparisons being made, though, that aren't quite apt: Megaman X and the Binding of Isaac. 

Compared with Isaac, the item pool feels painfully shallow. The game boasts 100+ items, but many of them fall under basic stat increases. Almost nothing in the item pool will define a run, will change the way you approach the game significantly. In Isaac, a player might start a run and find a powerup that makes every shot explode; this vastly changes how the player will engage enemies. 20XX is limited by its jump-n-shoot nature in that regard. 

Additionally, powerups don't quite synergize the way they do in Isaac. Rather, they seem to just stack as the player grows into a much more powerful version of the same Nina they started with. Sure there are double jumps and such, but there aren't really alternate paths a double jump could make available. Why? Because not every run will have a double jump. 

The level design has to exist, even in procedural generation, such that the player can get to everything with the basic kit. It feels like there are no secrets to find, no real rewards for exploration other than a chest containing a regular powerup. Megaman X crushes 20XX in this department.

The two comparable games also have lore. Megaman's is surface level and Isaac's is more esoteric, but 20XX has less of a story and more of a setting. The world feels hollow. 

Boss battles in 20xx are nothing like the ones from Megaman X. I have about 10 hours into the game and, even with a splash screen proclaiming the boss pre-fight, I can't remember any of their names. I tend to think of them as mask-wall-thing, bat boss, fire goat thing, chill penguin (oh, actually, I just remembered it's Shatterbeak), and the sunflower guy. Oh, and the wheel. They just don't do that much. It doesn't feel like the boss is fighting the player so much as just doing what it would normally do if you turned its power on. They're completely lifeless. 

The music is nice, but not memorable, with the boss battle music being particularly underwhelming. I should feel like I'm in a life or death battle. Instead, I feel like I'm gardening or something. Beating the bosses feels like housework. Oh, I just remembered; the boss weapons feel unnecessary, too. 

Overall, 20XX is fun for a bit, but limited. Do not go in expecting Megaman X. If I'm completely honest, it still feels like this game is in early access. It's good, really good, but not for very long.

36493283.review:
It's a procedural-generated (to some degree) indie love letter to Mega Man X.

If you've played any roguelike, "bullet hell" style, random environment games, then you know what I'm talking about. Combine all THAT into a Mega Man X clone, and you have this game.

Mega Man (the series in general) gets a lot of fan service, but the X series seems neglected. 20XX is all about MMX, right down to the controls (including dash), the 4-piece suit upgrade and red-colored, sword-wielding companion.

It's also not exactly the most punishing roguelike. So if you're curious about the roguelike genre, this is a good starter one. There's IS a hard mode, but in these games even the easy/normal modes tend to be difficult. I'd rate this g ame's normal mode as extremely fair.

So, if you like Mega Man games, especially the X series, and are into or curious about the roguelike genre, this game is for you.

My only complaints are that there's no real endgame, and it's not one unique stage per boss. I would have liked if each boss had its own stage type, and some kinda Sigma-esque supervillain final boss fight (at least one the first run).

36434217.review:
A really interesting Megaman/Megaman X/Megaman Zero inspired roguelite. With some caveats of criticism. This game isn't perfect. The procedural generation isn't fair and it takes some of the bad tropes of megaman, like the disappearing blocks, and places them everywhere in a little too much platforming and a little too little action. The enemies are interesting in some areas and generally boring in others. There really are only 4 level types to play and it was disappointing to see the bosses didn't each have their own unique area. The bosses get more HP and a few more tricks as you go through the upper levels, but only a few seem well done with this design and others seem blatantly unfair. Power Exploitation is fun for the bosses, but like some poorly designed Megaman weapons, you keep wishing they had more use than just for attacking. Some of the powers can be used to control traps in the areas, but it's lackluster due to the fact that the powers don't make the characters more accessible. 2 Shield powers, 2 Direct Shot powers, 2 Arcing mortar powers, a boomerang, and "melee crystal" that wishes it was a dash attacking power.

Megaman has some difficulty, but there is a difference between a mistake of the player and a mistake of the level. This game suffers more from the latter in it's design. Most damage taken from falls will feel more like an issue of the level design and less of a "This is a hard level" feel. I would suggest working more of the procedural generation to keep full blocks for well timed wall jumps and areas that encourage a little more fun of shooting/slashing enemies to pieces. Ride Armors were fun in the X games, and their placement could also add to the fun. While I like the core upgrades spiced around the area, the only one that feels complimentary to the level design is the hover. Furthermore, it would be interesting to have the leg parts be avaliable more frequently than the others. Maybe it's just my bad luck, but it always feels like the upgraded parts tend to come in order of Helm, Armor, Arm, Boots. The idea of the set bonuses are also pretty nice but I think the fact the Owlhawk and the Armatort share the hover feature feels a little disappointing. Maybe Owlhawk should have some sort of higher jump/slow fall instead?

If there were more powers, more bosses, more enemies, more levels, and a little less of the obviously cheap design, such as half block wall jumps, off timed lasers and platforms, and boxed in jumps that require the most perfect of bunny hops, this game would be a real masterpiece. As it is, it's an inspired concept that needs more polish. I'll continue to play it from time to time and I look forward to trying the Co-op later. I'm not 100% sure I could reccomend full price in it's current state. But it's a good buy for a sale.

Personally, I really enjoy this game. It feels like Mega Man meets Risk of Rain. Every play-through feels a little different due to your pick ups, which changes the way you play.

36407632.review:
Does both the Megaman X element and the roguelike element at about 70% proficiency. As such, while it's not worth getting at full price, it's a good casual X-like game to try out when discounted. Do keep the following issues in mind though:

The vanilla game primarily suffers from being too easy. It tries to extend its replayability through modifiers and hard modes, similarly to Risk of Rain, but without the base difficulty to back it up. The balance is okay but not the best, with the Zero-like melee character being significantly easier and stronger than his counterpart to the point where he makes the game a cakewalk.

The level design also suffers from a lack of longevity. The procedurally generated levels are not only simply not on par with the handcrafted well-designed levels of, say, X1-X3, but you're also bound to see a lot of repetition very soon, much like in Dirt 4 (which also died out largely due to a flawed tile-based generator which generated significant repetitiveness). As such, the difficulty quickly turns into simply making sure you're not killed by the swarm of increasingly tougher enemies, though in my experiences the upgrade rate for the Zero-like character can easily eclipse the rate at which the enemies grow in strength.

The bosses are also very simple and lack the strategic beauty of those in the X games. While boss weaknesses do exist, for the most part there's no real point in using them as both the buster and the saber greatly outclass them in the vast majority of situations, especially when focusing on damage upgrades.

Having said that though, the game quickly gets fast and thrilling, which, for me, is easily the game's strongest suit. It's something I felt the SNES X games always lacked simply by virtue of being on the overly clunky and slow SNES. It's more reminiscent of the Megaman Zero games in that sense, which, barring the weird design choice of going with ranks and having them be important for getting new weapons, I always felt were significantly better than the X games. It certainly wouldn't surprise me if they took some inspiration from the Z games, seeing as the ending features a reference to Z4. The roguelike element does add some variety to the game as well and encourages different playstyles without really infringing on the main X-like gameplay. I've heard people mention that the graphics aren't its strongest suit, but while they do indeed look less visually appealing than those of the X and Z games, they definitely get the job done - the animations are fluid and sensible, the enemies and attacks are easily to discern and there are no issues with the camera or anything of the sort. I got used to it in just a couple of levels, without having watched any gameplay footage before.

All in all, it's a good game to do a quick run of every now and then. It lacks the rewarding feeling of the X and Z games and the replayability of some of the top roguelike games, but for a casual bit of fun after work, especially when discounted, it's definitely worth considering.

36381511.review:
Dissenting opinion: as someone who grew up playing MMX 1-3, 20XX misses the mark. Instead of tightly designed levels, you get often-ugly procedural generation with chunks that become overly familiar after a few hours of play. Platforming never feels as tight as it could be, because your character's attributes are in constant flux. 20XX's action doesn't have the same impact/oomph/whatever as the SNES series. And I don't care much for the art style, sound and music; it's all overly bright and clownish.

That said, I like roguelikes and roguelites. I've sunk many hours into 20XX. The price is right, I don't regret my purchase. But if you go in expecting Mega Man X, you might be disappointed.

36367743.review:
20XX is many things. It is a platformer with snappy controls and challenging stage layouts and bosses; it is a roguelike with random level generation and gear upgrading over the course of many, many runs; but first and foremost, it is a Megaman love letter and deconstruction all at once.

This review comes from someone with no experience with Megaman X, and little with the classic games, so if you're in the same boat, here's what I think independently of the obvious comparisons.

In 20XX, you play as either Nina or Ace, two robotic "contractors" created and now hired by Drs. Brighton Sharp and Arlan Flat (DEFINITELY not Light and Wily) to stop what seems to be a manner of robot invasion or takeover. To get the job done, you'll need to face down eight different bosses, each with different patterns and weaknesses and their own themed stages built at random. You're going to need all manner of upgrades, help from a friendly training robot and a very tired robotic cat, and some platforming skill to receive your "payment" for a job well done.

The game just FEELS good to play, once you get used to the dashing and walljumping mechanics. The controls are responsive and platforming is fun, if occasionally difficult. This is also a bit more fair than what Megaman games I've played, though it IS pretty difficult and I still don't have a full clear. Combat is satisfying and upgrades are interesting, even if some are underwhelming or can get you used to bad habits in terms of gameplay (leading to some "damn you muscle memory").

It's really a game you have to learn by doing. Each boss you kill drops a version of one of its attacks, which you can pick up and use for yourself (up to three active at one time) or forego for an upgrade or some money (and yes, the currency really is called Nuts, they know exactly what they did there and they run with it). Each boss, as is Megaman tradition, has a weakness to another boss's weapon, so you want to plan your route through the levels if you want to exploit them. Each boss power also has an "additional" practical use, and it can be fun to figure out synergies and how to go about using them properly.

The art style is very bright and bouncy, the soundtrack is fantastic. The game can get a bit busy visually at times, especially in the later stages, and the later bosses can be teeth-grittingly difficult (looking at you, late-level Astrals). Most of the levels don't feel like a long grind, though be warned that an overall run can take quite a bit of time, at least 30 minutes (though you can save and quit after boss fights). It genuinely does not feel that long. There are various difficulty modes so you can scale up the challenge for yourself with special conditions, a daily and weekly challenge, a seeded mode, and a boss rush.

Oh, also points for the writing. The game's quite funny. Look at the Datalore when you get a chance!

Accessibility concerns:
The game is demanding visually especially at later levels. Things are moving very fast. Most things are clearly defined, but some platforms in Agnisort (fire/factory) levels can look like background elements, or background elements can look like platforms. Text describing upgrades and text in the Datalore entries is quite small and can't be scaled, however the UI can be scaled and changed between visual and numbers for easier understanding. Color differentation is somewhat important to distinguish the various "elite" enemies from each other (elites tend to have a black and red color palette) as well as pickups (green vs blue vs gray), and there are four different "core" armor sets corresponding to the colors pink, orange, yellow, and green, though these are distinguished by name and shape. The elite enemy designs might be sufficiently different, but I'm not colorblind.

As with any platformer, the game asks a lot of you physically, lots of button combos and dash-jumping is almost required, as is some level of button mashing. Controls are remappable, but the game recommends you play with a controller for a reason as a keyboard won't let you make all the required button presses at the same time. Powers are mapped to Y, LB, and LT on an Xbox-style controller by default, with dash being RT, A being jump, and X being shoot.

The game can get overwhelming at times with a lot going on, as should be expected with a platformer. There are a lot of sound effects happening at the same time. Hearing is mildly important to distinguish traps or enemy fire, though I wouldn't say it's required. Nina and Ace's grunting happens a lot and can quickly get VERY grating, so be warned.

The game contains brief flashes of light at some points, namely bosses. These are not sustained.



All in all, definite 8/10, glad I bought it, definitely worth it, there's lots to do. Though completionists beware. The achievements look hellish for this one.

36061617.review:
My recommendation is to NOT buy this game if you are expecting a clone of MegaMan X (like I did), but I did still find it very enjoyable. This game is supposed to appeal to X fans but it is a totally different game. Instead of writing a fat paragraph I have compiled a pros/cons list to give you an idea on what this game is about. Cons list may be a little long, but maybe it's because my MegaMan x nostalgia keeps kicking in since the X series were my favorite games of all time and still awaiting X9 which may never come out, but I do still recommend this game.

PROS:
-Addictive
-fluid controls
-fast-paced gameplay
-has online coop
-accumilate points to unlock power ups and bonuses
-gives you a choice when you defeat a boss to gain their weapon or pick other powerups
-when you die, you start everything over, so you have to make best of each run and choose your powerups wisely
-there are different type of helmet, buster, armor, etc. powerups that all do different things
-there are in game challenges that will grant you extra power ups
-every run you have will be different (1 run you may have a certain combo of powerups while in another run you'll have a different combination)

CONS:
-The music is not memorable (like it was in MegaMan x)
-Graphics kind of seem like you're playing a flash game (kind of)
-levels do not have much depth in them (even mighty no.9 had nice lengthy levels)
-bosses seem a bit too easy (however there are difficulties you can choose with "skulls" to add more of a challenge like the latest Halo games)
-you don't choose what level you want to enter when you begin to play like all of the MegaMan and MegaMan x series (you do choose from 3 everytime you beat a boss)
-there is only the weak buster attack and the charged up attack but no in between (like MegaMan X had)
-there are no hidden paths in the levels to find super secret power ups (like it was in X)
-not very story driven (but doesnt ruin the fun of the game)

I may have left some things out but you get the idea. Even though I recommend and enjoy this game a whole lot, it's not MegaMan x, and we may not ever get another MegaMan x. Times have changed and so has the way people play games nowadays. It's hard to let go of the past, but this game is a great way to bring you back to SOME lost memories.

PS I'm also the type of person that enjoyed mighty no. 9 despite the bad reviews - shoot me

35950819.review:
This is a game worth the price.

I bought this back when it FIRST hit Early Access and played it once before letting it sit in my library until it was released officially. I saw the potential back then but it needed a lot of polish.

It got that polish and so much more.

The rogue-like elements works perfectly in the Megaman format. The gist of it is every run, you start on a random boss and upon defeating the boss you choose from a random 3 out of the remaining 7. This is a great twist on the Megaman format of always going in the order of weaknesses being obtained and I would love to see the Devs start adding to the boss roster to really add more of that randomness.

The game scales its difficulty the farther in a run you go and often times will put your platforming skills to the test. That wouldn't go great if the controls didn't feel as fluid as they do. Especially after considering how it felt in those first few days of Early Access. The game has come a long way.

Honestly, it's worth picking up for anyone to just try out, Megaman fan or not. It's just a really fun game that has plenty of things for you to work towards and unlock and is definitely worth the $15 they are currently asking for. I look forward to the coming updates from the Devs now that Full Release is out and I hope to see the game expand and become more than it already is.

35936366.review:
This game is amazing, I notice some details that still remain in beta and the new char designs are really cool... THOUGH this is a positive review I will say that the ending of all the bosses is the most lengthy and repetitive part of the game. 
I think this game recreates mega man very well and is really nice for people like me who want to be engaged with a game, it helps you focus and stratagize for every single twist and turn.
The game starts off easily enough with by picking a random boss for you to fight, at the end of the boss fight you get a choice of several bosses they also being randomized.
Soon after you gain momentum you feel overpowered and like you're gonna fly... oh don't present yourself to 20XX just yet...
After the eight boss, that was it in beta, that was the end, it was rip your run, You've one! But oh no no no... in this version you'll despise the end of your run.
Have you ever played one of the crazy over the top japanese bullet hells? Then imagine that, but on a 2D sidescroller with some potiential fuck up depending on your run. If you got flight boots, You're a lucky one, Air Dash? Yeah you're lucky, now if you don't have any of those? Either restart your run, or prepare for a hell of a time.
The game will designate enemies to block your path to lower your hp, and that makes it borderline impossible to fight the 2nd final boss, he's just a mixture of boss attacks with a little protect beetle which is annoying but still easier then the actual stage.
Finally the Last stage, yes, you don't just fight the other boss right away, you have to go through yet another lovely unforgiving stage that will dwindle your HP and NRG, be sure you have the bolts necessary to buy hp and shop items cuz your NRG will be dead for the majority of these stages.
The final boss is cool at first but then becomes a repetitive mess and leaves your hands sweaty and slightly unsatisfied...
THEN have that you go though yet another segment that is even more hell then the final 2, again, horrible and unfair places and lava pits, luckily no traps, but you'll be fighting alot of enemies going through the final stage, some not hostile, some there to drain the remaining hp from your sorry sorry hp bar.
The end segment will not be like how Isaac's is, where you're either super OP or not, it will bleed you out of everything you own before giving you the conclusion.
It's such a good game. But the end game will not make you feel good and it will demoralize you, even when you beat the final boss, it just isn't satisfactory, it makes you work for that final damned cutscene...

Overall I give this game a 9.5. its so awesome, the music is amazing, the enemies telegraph nicely and you can tell what their about just by looking at them, and the graphics are bright and happy.

But that end Segment will make you bleed and make you say/regret alot of items you wished you had.

35925012.review:
this is the kind of game that makes you happy about the indie game movement. it's a game made by gamers specifically to fill a niche of game that they (and others) have always wanted to play. it's like those people who made a metroidvania because they wanted more of those games to play. you gotta respect that. in this case it's Mega Man X fans attempting to capture a co-op experience. this would be admirable if nothing else, but a slavish devotion to recapture the general feeling of MMX ensures that from aesthetic to mechanics to physics you always feel that similarity. it's mostly appreciated, though at times overly derivative. the inspirational source would've been obvious without copying even the tiniest details like the silly boss names, while i would have personally liked to see the game twist its own identity in there a bit more.

regardless a co-op MMX experience is a great idea and this delivers. it's an easy recommendation to anyone who simply yearns for a game of that nature. i struggle somewhat with the amount of action going on in this fast-paced widescreen game, but i also have not practiced much in single player. if there is a potential for frustration it's mitigated by short play times to complete an entire run, customizable difficulty options, and instant replayability.

Throughout the levels you gain nuts which can be traded for health and temporary power-ups. You also collect soul chips, which stay with you after death. I've only made it to around level 5, and the difficulty slowly ramped up between each level of a run. I don't have much time in this game due to what I call "Netflix syndrome", a.k.a I have too many games to try to get to, but I can see myself returning to this game for extended periods in the future. If you're still on the fence, wait for it to go on sale. If you like Mega Man and Rogue Legacy then I'm sure you'll get enjoyment out of this title.

PS, I should note it does have co-op, but it's been a year or so since I last tried co-op so I don't want to comment too much on it. But, last I tried the net-code was iffy at best.

35879365.review:
很可惜，STEAM没有中性评价。考虑再三决定选择推荐。想给不推荐是因为这个游戏的[u]应用程式崩溃问题[/u]和[u]兼容性问题[/u]在我连续反映了3次更新之后依旧没有修复！极易触发！
《20XX》作为一款向Rockman（洛克人）致敬的游戏，横向对比来说非常成功。对比官方作品而言，难度俨然降低了不少（挑衅模式全开头骨不算）。有着自己的2D卡通风格以及自己的[strike]（烧死恩爱狗）[/strike]故事线
亮点：
1.采用2D卡通风格，建模很精细，人物（怪物）特征清晰可辨。
2.除了最为经典的射手“Nina”，还加入了“Ace”这种近战武士。（虽然关卡对Ace并不怎么友好）
2.“嘲讽力度十足的”游戏翻译，对于手残玩家简直是神一样的补刀，犹如这个部门的名字——“伤口恶化部”。
（在任何地方都是）
3.道具种类较多，较为丰富。虽然并没有类似于《以撒的结合》的道具可以相互之间发生连锁反应的设定。
4.游戏节奏比较快，单次竞跑跑完全程平均用时40分钟。
5.核心装备的出现。游戏内一共有4套核心装备，能凑齐一套基本这局竞跑就通关了。
6.武器种类丰富，每一位角色都有5种可选武器。
7.BGM很有电子音乐风格，可以很好的配合游戏节奏（送快递）。
8.BOSS间相生相克。一种BOSS武器对一个BOSS很有效，对另一个就不是了。
不足：
1.虽然游戏时间比较短，平均40分钟可以跑完全程。但是相比而言游戏玩法单一，一局竞跑后基本没有欲望进行第二轮。第二天除外。绝地岛等队友必备。
2.应用的崩溃问题。Win10 专业版64位（正版激活）上崩溃问题很常见，甚至是跳出来一个系统提示都能导致游戏直接崩溃，调整分辨率也会。其他操作系统暂时不详。 
3.“随机的网络化游戏”仅针对每日竞跑/每日硬派等有排行榜的竞跑。
4.通关要求太低了。一个“诺娃力场”，一个“烈焰护盾”，一个“寒冰刺”，以及一套绿核心就可以保证你打完全程了。
5.难度分配不均匀。挑衅模式相比而言太难，标准模式太简单，恭敬（3条命）模式居然比标准模式难！

附：我已知的BOSS克制关系
旋转飞刀       克制  迫击炮
迫击炮           克制  诺娃力场[spoiler]（不是诺瓦露力场）[/spoiler]
维拉机关枪    克制  昆特激光 （注：机关枪可以击退昆特激光变得对你无害）
烈焰盾牌       克制   寒冰刺

35768553.review:
TL;DR: a technically amazing game that does some pretty unbelievable things with RNG. It gets a bit too obsessed with RNG, some things would have been much better being pre-generated, but it's an awesome platformer that any Mega Man fan should try.

Full disclosure- I'm a huge Megma Man fan, especially of the X series. So if I'm biased- that's the reason.

This has got to be one of the most inventive platformers I've ever player. And it's all RNG. Even now, I can't believe how much of it is randomly generated. And the game doesn't feel like a horrific patchwork of stage design like some other RNG-reliant games do. Stages have a great flow to them, they're just short enough that they don't overstay their welcome while still managing to show off their respective gimmicks. 

But probably my favorite thing about this game is how easily you can "break" it, and how it just doesn't care. See, pretty early on in a run, you can get leg upgrades that let you do some creative platforming. And with them, you can skip huge chunks of a stage. And the game manages to dissuade you from doing that: if you skip too much of a level, you risk missing some loot or health pickups. So that's a nice risk/reward balance right there. You're encouraged to explore, but if you want to speed run the game, you can easily do that, and the game supports it.

The soundtrack is also great. I was kind of expecting some Jrock a la MMX, and they kinda went with generic "indie music". But it's good generic indie music, so I don't care.

You can also customize the game's difficulty by playing on Defiant (hard) mode and activating or deactivating certain modifiers. Some of them just make the game more frustrating or remove cool features, such as this cat that you can buy that drops chests a certain levels that just won't be there in Defiant difficulty, but others do make for an interesting challenge.

Sadly, the bosses aren't great as the stages. They're kind of a joke. Most of them can be beaten by just mashing the attack button. Since almost everytihng in the game deals only 1 damage to you, you can only die from excessive chip damage. So the only benefit bosses have versus regular enemies is large health bars. And even those can be burnt to nothing with a few damage upgrades.

But while we're on the topic of bosses, they do look pretty cool. But in a reverse of the bosses are too easy problem, bosses are the only enemies that are visually interesting. Jim Sterling said that they look like Pokemon. I agree, they do. Unfortunately, they look like 4th generation pokemon.

The game also has some pretty serious communication problems. When you pick up upgrades, they're described in al ine or two of text. And these descriptions can be either perfectly adequate (attacks deal more damage) or uninformative. Or worse- they can be decieving. The developers chose to describe a lot of items and upgrades using baby talk, probably to come off as whimsical or to try being funny. Sadly, that often comes at the cost of telling you what an upgrade actually does. One of the two playable characters can get a big axe. The game describes it as something along the lines of "deals massive damage, but very slow". "Slow" isn't the actual handicap of the weapon- it has a horrible, uniterruptible aerial attack. Would've been nice to know about that before I bought it. Or, the game has "very safe labs" that can give you powerful upgrades that come with significant downsides. One of them says "damage massively increased. For everyone." I thought that that means that only enemies deal more damage, and not environmental hazards like spikes, because it said "Everyone", not "Everything". The game lied there. Everything deals more damage.

Also, the game could really use some RNG controls. Sometimes, the RNG can actually cut whole features out of the game. For example- "Glory Zones" are mini-stages that you can find that provide with core upgrades- the game's equivalent of armor upgrades in MMX- when completed. These are awesome. They're pretty challenging, but give you worthwhile rewards for finishing them. But because whether or not they appear at all is RNG, you could (and probably will) have entire runs without them. Why? Why not give players an option to increase or decrease the likelihood of them appearing? You can later buy an upgrade that makes Glory Zones appear in every level, and it makes the game considerably more enjoyable. Why is that an upgrade and not a toggleabple menu option?

Also, let's go back to those core upgrades. They're also awesome. They give you interesting bonuses and can improve you platforming abilities by a whole bunch. And when you finish a matching armor set, you get some very, very impressive new power (such as dashing in the air three consequitve times, bye bye stages). But that also amplifies the RNG problem- the game doesn't care which armor upgrades you already have, so your chances of completing a whole set are very low. I've played the game a lot, and even so I could only complete two out of four armor sets, and even that was due to dumb luck.

But even so, it's a marvel that the game manages to be this fun when everytihng is randomly generated. It's as fun as some of the better MMX titles. Hell, it's probably better than them and I'm probably just blinded by nostalgia. And I know I've written a lot about its downsides but, well, that's only because they're very glaring in light of an otherwise awesome game.

If you're a fan of sidescrolling platformers, buy it. If you're a fan of Mega Man, you probably already have.

35687988.review:
TLDR: If you miss megaman X, this game will scratch that itch for you.

A good replica of the megaman X series with rouge-lite elements. There are 10 bosses including final boss and stages are limited to 4 themes with challenging platforming. 

Theres also a boss rush mode for those who don't care for platforming.

Note on upgrades, they're mostly passive boosts and there are some alternate weapons for Nina and Ace.

Only nitpick I have is that we don't get to keep armor pieces and you'll have to randomly find them whenever you start a new run. Personally I loved collecting armor and would prefer those to be permanent instead of passive upgrades.

35680000.review: With a controller, this game has some of the best platforming mechanics I've experienced in quite awhile. The game can be as fast-paced or as slow as you want it, but the platforming remains crisp throughout, which is what makes this game so solid. I see a lot of reviews saying the controls are trash, but I don't know what they're talking about. I will admit that I find Nina pretty boring; I think the real gem of the game is the melee-only Ace. Without crisp controls, this would be just another Megaman knockoff, but the marriage of changing levels, bumpin' music, and solid controls solidifies this as "well worth your time" on the money-to-gameplay ratio.

35606040.review:
Although it would be nothing without it's ancestors, there is no question that 20XX deserves a place on the shelf among them. 
-Classic MegamanX style mechanics: easy to pick up for beginners and veterans.
-Rogue-Like structure gives a large variety of power ups that change how you play from run to run.
-Scaling difficulty: Later levels will add stonger enemies, extra traps, and more complex bosses depending on what order they are played
-Replayability: Achievements and difficulty modifiers garuntee you will always have another challenge to try for.
-A short but strong melody-driven soundtrack that i am still not sick of.
definitely worth the price tag for both the game and soundtrack.

35591693.review:
Honestly, there's a lot to hate about this game. For one thing, and I'm sorry if the developer ends up reading this but the visual design just isn't very good. I by no means could draw anything remotely close, but visually it looks very amateurish, and reminds me of the sort of things that friends of mine would have been drawing in middle school. Charming in its own way, but a bit strange to me for a purchased product. I understand that this game isn't coming from even a small studio, but there are plenty of indie games that have a more polished look to them over all.

Next, our stand-in for Zero feels useless on most levels, with the X stand in being far superior. I won't blame the devs for this too much. The nature of the game being randomly generated just sort of makes it feel like our X would in general be the superior character because they've got a ranged ability. On the plus side, this game does not force you to play as different heros! You can both be the X-equivalent or the Zero-equivalent at the same time, one of you implying playing a pallet swap. That's a huge plus for me.

On the much more minor side, I can say that this game does and doesn't support ultrawide (21:9 aspect ratio) monitors. While I find the normal stages render to the entire screen, the daily challenges or whatever they're called render in 16:9 letterbox. I'm not sure why. I don't really mind it all that much, I expected the game to do 21:9 with 16:9 pillar-boxing, it's just strange that it works in one and not the other. I'm sure there's a reason.

Now, let's move on to positive, because now that I believe most of my gripes are out of the way, I do have a lot of positive things to say. First off, the game *feels* right in terms of how it handles. While the level design can sometimes be lacking, I feel like I'm playing a Mega Man X game, from the way you slide down walls, to the dash, or the dash-jump combo. It all feels right, and that's great. The game also runs very smooth and doesn't feel sluggish ever.  The games greatness weakness, the randomly generatedness, is also its greatest strength. There appears to be a lot to do in this game, and I doubt I'll ever become completely bored with it!

It's Mega Man X with Co-op guys! For a guy who really loves the series and only has one friend who really loves it too, this was a dream come true to me! You should have seen the look on my face when I was trying to find something that the both of us would enjoy playing with each other and I found a literal dream come true. I don't care about the negatives, this is a great find and I'll be logging a LOT more hours in the game than I currently have. (Probably sitting at around 3-4 hours at the time of writing?)

I'm sure some would say the music isn't going to win any awards, but I quite like it and I'm happy that I bought the soundtrack. It fits the game well. I might add more to this review in the future because I've just scratched the surface, but I'd say despite whatever negatives this game might have if you've got a friend and you both love Mega Man X style games, absolutely buy this. If you're alone, I'd almost definitely say buy it. This fills a void that's been filled by essentially nothing since the release of X7.

P.S.

Really a minor complaint but, for the life of me I'm not sure why you have the default dash bound to I believe one of the triggers or should button. I instantly rebound it to the b on the Xbox 360 controller, because that's what the dash button would have been in the Mega Man X1-3 games, and I'm pretty sure most of the series as well on the equivalent controller. Executing a jump-dash just doesn't feel as easy or as right with the current setup. Not a big deal though-- buttons are rebindable, and I'm sure there's a reason for it that I'm simply just not seeing yet.

I quite honestly can't say enough good things about this game.
